s.text: --Howard Nathan, adviser to Pennsylvania's governor, refers either to his state's new "Give a Kidney, Get a Toaster" plan, or to its offer of a $300 death benefit to the family of any organ donor.
well, actually, he does refer to shows like Friends .
--TV producer Norman Lear refers either to shows like Friends or ...
--Orville Schell, dean of the journalism school at University of California, Berkeley, refers either to Pamela Anderson's breast reduction, or to USA Today 's decision to run ads on their front page.
--Kenneth Keller, marketing director for Heinz Ketchup, refers either to biologically altered chickens born in the shape of letters of the alphabet, or to putting ketchup on stuff.
--Geologist Craig Feible refers either to the NYPD or to the extraordinary skill of ancient stone toolmakers revealed at a newly discovered site in Kenya.
--Karen Jurgensen, editor of USA Today , refers either to the previous joke, or to the difference between news and ads.
"Oh, sure, Randy, the war may seem funny now, but what if our killing all those people inspires a violent video game?
(It is curious how few pundits connected Kosovo and Columbine, two stories displayed side by side on every front page for weeks--hmmm, where would these kids get these violent ideas?)
(It is curious how few pundits connected Kosovo and Columbine, two stories displayed side by side on every front page for weeks--hmmm, where would these kids get these violent ideas?)
